title-group.article-title: Exogenous chromosomes reveal how sequence composition drives chromatin assembly, activity, folding and compartmentalization

abstract.p: Genomic sequences co-evolve with DNA-associated proteins to ensure the multiscale folding of long DNA molecules into functional chromosomes. In eukaryotes, different molecular complexes organize the chromosome’s hierarchical structure, ranging from nucleosomes and cohesin-mediated DNA loops to large scale chromatin compartments. To directly explore the causal relationships between the DNA sequence composition and the spontaneous loading and activity of these DNA-associated complexes in the absence of co-evolution, we characterized chromatin assembly and activity in yeast strains carrying exogenous bacterial chromosomes that diverged from eukaryotic sequences over 1.5 billion years ago. Combining this synthetic approach with a deep learning-based analysis, we show that, in this cellular context, the sequence composition drives nucleosome assembly, transcriptional activity, cohesin-mediated looping, and chromatin compartmentalization. These results are a step forward in understanding the molecular events at play during natural horizontal gene transfers as well as synthetic genomics engineering projects.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Genomic sequences coevolve with molecular complexes to regulate processes such as gene expression, DNA replication and the functional organization of the genome in 3D. This interdependence raises intriguing questions in light of transfer of genetic material across species such as horizontal gene transfers (HGT), introgression, and invasion by DNA viruses or retrotransposons 1–4, since the base composition (e.g.GC%) of these elements can significantly diverge from their host’s genome (e.g. the introgression of a 12% GC-divergent 1Mb sequence in Lachancea kluyveri 5). In the synthetic genomics field, large DNA molecules carrying entire exogenous metabolic and genetic pathways are introduced into chassis microbial strains or cell lines 6–12. How the host genome copes with these exogenous sequences remains unclear, with some studies reporting variable levels of transcription by the host cell 6,13, outlining the need to better understand how an exogenous DNA molecule is processed by a host’ molecular machinery. Addressing this question also holds significant promise for our understanding of host genome metabolism, as it means better characterizing the molecular processes involved. The sequence composition of genomes can vary between different species (e.g. 20 to 65% GC), but also within genomes. Local sequence composition is related to chromatin activity, with high GC regions on average enriched in actively transcribed sequences 14. Chromatin structure also depends on underlying sequence composition at the nucleosomal level 15, and on the activity of structural maintenance of chromosome (SMCs) ring complexes (e.g. cohesin) 16–18 at higher-order levels. In GC-rich gene-rich regions, CTCF binding to chromatin leads to the formation of cohesin-mediated loops and topologically associating domains (TADs). In contrast, in AT-rich, inactive regions, CTCF binding sites are often methylated leading to the absence of these structures 19. In addition, variations in sequence composition along metazoan and plant chromosomes also correlate with the global genome 3D fold, as chromatin organized on sequences of similar composition tends to coalesce in distinct compartments 20,21. In contrast, the shorter, compact genomes of eukaryotic microorganisms such as budding yeast do not exhibit large GC variations, nor compartments.

Here we explore the causal relationships between the DNA sequence and the structure and activity of chromatin, including transcription, replication, and multiscale 3D organization. To this end, we explore the behavior of entire bacterial chromosomes with highly divergent GC contents introduced in the S. cerevisiae genome. We map nucleosome assembly, polymerase activity and cohesin binding and show that regions with different GC contents lead to different regional chromatinization profiles. These regions self-associate in 3D leading to the spontaneous formation of active / inactive chromosomal compartments similar to the ones observed in complex multicellular organisms. In parallel, we trained neural networks (NN) on the chromatin profiles along native yeast chromosomes to learn their sequence determinants and predict that the sequence composition spontaneously determines the fate of any DNA molecule introduced into a given cellular context, including its organization from nucleosome positioning up to 3D folding and transcriptional activity.

sec.title: Adaptation of supernumerary bacteria chromosomes to yeast
sec.p: To investigate the behavior of large sequences which have not evolved in a eukaryotic context, we exploited S. cerevisiae strains carrying an extra 17th circular chromosome made either from the Mycoplasma mycoides subsp. mycoides (referred to as “Mmyco”) or Mycoplasma pneumoniae (“Mpneumo”) genomes (Methods; Table S1). We linearised these chromosomes, which contain a yeast centromeric sequence and an autonomous replication sequence (ARS) allowing them to self-replicate and segregate 22. (Figure 1a; Supplementary Figure 1a; Method; see also Supplementary Figure 2 and results). While the GC content of S. cerevisiae is 38%, the GC content of the Mmyco and Mpneumo chromosomes 24% and 40%, respectively (Figure 1a). These chromosomes do not impose a significant fitness cost on their eukaryotic host, since each strain displays similar growth rates compared to their parental strains in selective media (Supplementary Figure 1b) with an estimated segregation rate similar to a centromeric plasmid 23 (Supplementary Figure 1c).

sec.title: Spontaneous chromatinization of bacterial chromosomes in a eukaryotic context
sec.p: We profiled the chromatin landscape of both Mmyco and Mpneumo strains, and of a parental wild-type strain, by performing MNase-seq, and H3, H2A, RNA polymerase II (PolII) and cohesin (Scc1) ChIP-seq experiments (Methods; Supplementary Figure 3a).

Strikingly, the chromatin composition of bacterial sequences varies greatly depending on which chromosome is inserted. Genome-wide profiles along the Mpneumo chromosome appear similar to wild-type (WT) yeast chromosomes (compare Figure 1b, panel i with ii). Locally, Scc1 peaks across the Mpneumo chromosome display a strong signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) (Figure Supplementary Figure 3g), and are preferentially located in nucleosome-depleted and PolII enriched regions, as observed for Scc1 peaks located in yeast chromosomes of the same strain (Figure Supplementary Figure 3h). In sharp contrast, profiles in the Mmyco strain showed several differences from the profiles found in the parental WT strain (compare Figure 1b, panel iii with i). Firstly, ChIP-seq profiles of histones H2A and H3 show that these two histones are present along the Mmyco chromosome, but MNase-seq signal is nevertheless strongly reduced (Figure 1b, Supplementary Figure 3b). We found that poly(dA) and poly(dT) tracks, which repel nucleosomes, are over-represented on Mmyco, while AA/TT 10-bp periodicity, which facilitates DNA bending around histone cores, is reduced (Supplementary Figure 3c,d). These results suggest that histones can bind the Mmyco chromosome but cannot form well-assembled nucleosomes. MNase has more affinity for AT-rich sequences 24 and this property may also decrease the MNase-seq coverage along Mmyco.

Secondly, the average PolII profile along Mmyco is lower than typical WT profiles (Figure 1b), whereas Scc1 is enriched over the whole Mmyco chromosome, without the distinct peaks observed on endogenous chromosomes. Scc1 levels also appear strongly and moderately reduced at centromeres and along the arms of the endogenous S. cerevisiae chromosomes, respectively (Figure 1b, panel i and panel iii, Supplementary Figure 3e). This suggests that the Mmyco chromosome titrates predominantly a dynamic pool of cohesins at yeast centromeres during metaphase, and less so the stable cohesins involved in sister chromatid cohesion along the arms.

These results show that large exogenous bacterial chromosomes placed in a eukaryotic context spontaneously display some eukaryotic chromatin characteristics: histones, polII and cohesins all bind bacterial DNA irrespectively of GC content. However, striking differences in the observed chromatin profiles led us to define two chromatin types. The chromatin landscape over Mpneumo, whose 40% GC content is close to the native S. cerevisiae GC content, is similar to the landscape found on yeast chromosomes. We will hereafter refer to this type of chromatin as “Y” for yeast-like. On the other hand, the chromatin landscape over Mmyco, with a low 24% GC content, displays flatter patterns for nucleosomes, polII and cohesins, with lower average values for both well-assembled nucleosomes and polII and an unusual high value for cohesins in G2. We will hereafter refer to this type of chromatin as “U” for unstructured.

sec.title: GC content drives chromatin composition of exogenous chromosomes
sec.p: The different GC content values of Mmyco and Mpneumo prompted us to investigate if the GC content could explain the establishment of Y and U chromatin. To do so, we turned to convolution neural networks (CNN), a computational approach increasingly used in genomics to learn genome annotations from the underlying DNA sequence 25,26 (Supplementary Figure 1d). We trained CNNs to learn MNase-seq, and Scc1 or PolII ChIP-seq profiles using yeast chromosomes I to XV sequences (Methods) 27. For each strain, the trained CNNs predict these three profiles with good accuracy on the held out sequence of yeast chromosome XVI (correlation of 0.41, 0.55 and 0.45 for MNase, Scc1 ChIP and PolII ChIP signals, respectively; Figure 2a-c), confirming that genomic sequence is a primary determinant of the chromatin landscape 27–31. Note that individual cohesin peaks at centromeres were not correctly predicted by the trained NN (Figure 2b).

Next, we applied the trained CNNs to Mmyco and Mpneumo sequences and found that the rules learned on yeast sequences were sufficient to predict the features experimentally characterized on both exogenous sequences. Not only the predictions correctly recapitulate the features of Y chromatin on Mpneumo, but also the U chromatin features on Mmyco sequences, notably: (1) a lower MNase-seq coverage; (2) a broad enrichment of Scc1, with no discrete peaks and (3) an absence of PolII peaks (Figure 2a-c).

To further characterize the link between the GC content and the chromatin composition and activity, we predicted the MNase-seq, PolII and Scc1 ChIP-seq profiles on artificial, randomly generated 30 kb sequences with variable GC contents ranging from 0 to 100 % (Figure 2d-f, Methods). All predicted signals display a strong variability with respect to the GC content. The Mnase average occupancy observed along endogenous chromosomes was only recovered for a GC % between 40 and 60, whereas for higher and lower values it was strongly decreased. The cohesin signal showed a gradual decrease for increasing GC %, and the PolII signal was predicted to be minimal between 20 and 40 % and increased strongly for smaller and larger values. These predictions are in good agreement with the experimental results obtained for both bacterial and yeast sequences, suggesting that the trained CNNs are indeed able to correctly predict these patterns on a broad range of sequences.

Taken together, these findings show that the GC content of any sequence, either exogenous or endogenous, is a major determinant of the spontaneous establishment of the chromatin and functional landscape of a given species.

sec.title: Transcriptional activity of bacterial genomes in a yeast context
sec.p: We next explored whether transcription occurs on the bacterial chromosomes harboring either Y or U chromatin types by performing total, stranded RNA-seq analysis (Figure 3a,b; Method). Consistent with PolII ChIP-seq profiles (Figure 1b), the whole Mpneumo chromosome is transcribed to levels similar to those of endogenous yeast chromosomes (Figure 3a ii). Mpneumo transcription tracks are significantly longer than yeast genes (4.9 kb vs 3.4 kb, p-value < 2e-4) and do not systematically display clear boundaries (Figure 3b). Transcription along Mpneumo does not preferentially occur over bacterial gene bodies nor seem to initiate at bacterial TSSs, also consistent with an absence of PolII enrichment at these loci (Supplementary Figure 4a-c).

While the Y chromatin type found on Mpneumo is transcribed, the Mmyco U chromatin type is only sparsely and lowly transcribed (Figure 3a iii), again in good agreement with the poor levels of PolII deposition (Figure 1b). This silencing is not correlated with the recruitment of the SIR Sir2/3/4 complex (Supplementary Figure 4d) and likely reflects the impairment of a proper nucleosomal organization with clear nucleosome depleted regions, known to be required at TSS 32.

Surprisingly, the orientation of transcription tracks of the two bacterial chromosomes in a yeast environment follows, on average, the orientation of the bacterial genes annotated along these sequences although the transcription machinery has diverged billions years ago (Figure 3c, see the orientation of genes and stranded tracks in Figure 3b).

sec.title: Interplay between transcription and cohesin localization
sec.p: On yeast and Mpneumo chromosomes cohesin accumulates during G2/M at sites of convergent transcription, as expected (Lengronne et al. 2004; Glynn et al. 2004) (Figure 3b, green dotted lines, Supplementary Figure 4e). Comparison of the Scc1 ChIP-seq and stranded RNA-seq profiles over the Mpneumo chromosome suggests that in Y chromatin regions sharper cohesin peaks are associated with sharper transcriptional convergence (Figure 3b, arrows) and that the strongest Scc1 peaks are correlated with a stronger transcriptional convergence (Figure 3d, Supplementary Figure 4f, Methods). In sharp contrast, high cohesin levels span the entire transcriptionally silent U chromatin regions of Mmyco, with no clear peaks, most likely reflecting the lack of convergent transcription sites (Figure 1b and Figure 3b). Taken together, these results suggest that cohesin can bind DNA in absence of active transcription (and/or of proper chromatinization) in vivo, but accumulates at convergent transcription sites only in presence of active transcription.

sec.title: Spatial organization of exogenous bacterial chromosomes in a eukaryote context
sec.p: To assess the 3D organization of Y and U chromatin types, we performed capture of chromosome conformation (Hi-C) experiments 20,35 on the Mmyco or Mpneumo strains arrested either in G1 or G2/M (Figure 4a, b).

In G1-arrested cells, yeast chromosomes exhibit the expected Rabl configuration, with clustered centromeres and subtelomeric regions colocalizing at the nuclear periphery, resulting in a dotted pattern in Hi-C contact maps 36–38. For both Mmyco and Mpneumo chromosomes, the added yeast centromeric sequence clusters with the native yeast centromeres.

However, the two bacterial chromosomes, being either covered with Y or U chromatin, exhibited very distinct structural characteristics (Figure 4a). The Y-type Mpneumo chromosome behaves as an endogenous S. cerevisiae chromosome (Figure 4a): (1) the trans-contacts (Supplementary Figure 5a) and long-range cis-contacts (Figure 4c) are similar to those found for yeast chromosomes; (2) the slope of the p(s) averaged contact probability as a function of the genomic distance (s) is close to -1.5 both for yeast and Mpneumo chromosomes, a value corresponding to the typical polymer structure observed in simulations (Figure 4c) 39; (3) DNA-FISH labeling of Mpneumo DNA reveals an extended and contorted structure within the intranuclear space, confirming the intermixing of the chromosome with the actively transcribed native chromosomes (Figure 4e, Supplementary Figure 5g,h). In contrast, in the U-type Mmyco chromosome, (1) only few trans-contacts with the endogenous chromosomes were detected (Supplementary Figure 5a), and predominantly with the 32 yeast subtelomeric regions (Figure 4a, dotted rectangles; Supplementary Figure 5b); (2) the slope of the p(s) curve also changes dramatically towards a value of -1 at shorter distances, corresponding to a polymer globule (Figure 4c) 20; (3) DNA-FISH labeling of the Mmyco chromosome confirmed the globular conformation of the chromosome and revealed its preferential position at the nuclear periphery, reflecting its proximity with sub/telomeres (Figure 4e; Supplementary Figure 5g,h).

We then generated Hi-C contact maps of both strains synchronized in G2/M. In yeast, chromosome compaction and individualization in G2/M-arrested cells reflect cohesin-mediated chromatin folding into arrays of loops. This compaction results in a typical p(s) curve that presents an inflection point around the average loop length 38,40,41. The decrease of interchromosomal contacts (Figure 4b, Supplementary Figure 5a) and the change in p(s) (Figure 4d, Supplementary Figure 5c,d) observed for both native and bacterial chromosomes indicate mitotic compaction of both Y and U chromatin types, although they display different contact patterns at short scales. Endogenous yeast and Mpneumo chromosomes exhibit focal enrichments of medium-range contacts corresponding to anchored loops (black triangles on Figure 4f) 40,42,43. 59 loops were called across the Mpneumo chromosome, spanning over slightly longer genomic distances (28 kb on average) than the loops found along yeast sequences (22 kb) (Supplementary Figure 5e). The dotted grid pattern in Mpneumo is reminiscent of multiple DNA loops observed along mammalian interphase chromosomes 44. This suggests that some loop anchors have the ability to be involved in loops of various sizes, a phenomenon not observed across native S. cerevisiae chromosomes (Figure 4f). On the other hand, Mmyco chromosome, albeit covered by cohesin, displayed a strikingly different pattern with no visible loops (Figure 4g), suggesting that cohesins are able to promote compaction but that the loop anchors are not preferentially positioned along U chromatin. Overall, these observations highlight two different spatial configurations of Mmyco and Mpneumo exogenous chromosomes. On the one hand, the inactive Mmyco chromosome in G1 is compacted and positioned at the periphery of the nucleus, away from the active chromosome set. Upon S-phase and G2 arrest, the DNA is further compacted in a cohesin dependent manner with no visible loops at discrete positions. On the other hand, the active Mpneumo chromosome behaves as endogenous yeast chromosomes, displaying discrete mitotic DNA loops in G2/M.

sec.title: Cohesin compacts exogenous bacterial chromosomes in yeast
sec.p: Mmyco and Mpneumo chromosomes display different Scc1 binding landscapes (Figure 1b, 1c), and we therefore investigated the relationship between cohesin deposition patterns and the corresponding contact maps. In yeast, cohesin peaks correspond to the loop anchors in metaphase Hi-C maps 40,42,43. Along Mpneumo, strong Scc1 peaks are also close to anchors with a median spacing of 566 bp between consecutive anchors) (Figure 4f, 4h). This suggests that these loops are formed through the process of loop extrusion (LE) by which cohesin complexes organize DNA by capturing small loops and gradually enlarging them 45,46. To test this hypothesis, we performed Hi-C in absence of the cohesin-holocomplex member Wpl1 (human Wapl), which impairs cohesin removal and typically results in longer loops readily visible by a shift of the inflection point in the p(s) curve 43,46. In absence of Wpl1, we observed increased long-range contacts in all chromosomes, including Mmyco and Mpneumo (Figure 4i; Supplementary Figure 5f), in agreement with extended loop formation. These results show that Y and U chromatin are prone to cohesin-dependent loop extrusion in G2/M, although the generated loops are not focally stabilized along the Mmyco chromosome.

sec.title: Mosaic chimeric chromosomes display spontaneous, chromatin type-dependent DNA compartmentalization
sec.p: The structural and functional features of the Y- and U-type chromatin are reminiscent of the euchromatin and heterochromatin described along metazoan chromosomes 20. We therefore wondered whether they can coexist on a single chromosome. Using CRISPR-Cas9, we first fused the Mmyco chromosome with the native yeast chromosome XVI (XVIfMmyco chromosome). We then induced translocations to generate two other strains with chromosomes harboring alternating U and Y chromatin regions as small as 50 kb (XVIfMmycot1 and XVIfMmycot2; Figure 5a; Supplementary Figure 6a-c Methods). ChIP-seq profiles of RNA PolII on Mmyco regions were similar before and after translocation, demonstrating that PolII binding is independent of the broader regional context (Supplementary Figure 6d). The overall Hi-C contact maps of XVIfMmyco strain synchronized in G1 showed little differences compared to the parental Mmyco strain (but for the deleted and fused regions; e.g. Lazar-Stefanita et al. 2022; Shao et al. 2018) (Figure 5b, compare panel i with ii). The Y-type chr. XVI arm intermixes with the other 15 yeast chromosomes while the U-type Mmyco arm remains isolated from the rest of the genome, contacting subtelomeric regions (Figure 5b). In the translocated strains, however, the alternating chromatin type regions resulted in striking checkerboard contact patterns within XVIfMmycot1 and XVIfMmycot2 chromosomes (Figure 5b, panels iii and iv). This pattern reflects the fact that U-type regions make specific contacts over long distances, bypassing the Y-type regions found in between (Figure 5c; Supplementary Figure 6e G1). Similarly, Y-type regions of chromosome XVI also are also involved in specific Y-Y contacts over longer distances (Figure 5c). Intra U and Y regions contact decay is also different in the two chromatin types, U chromatin being prone to longer range contacts in cis (Supplementary Figure 6e). These results unambiguously show that alternate GC-regular Y and GC-poor U regions along chromosomes are spontaneously segregated within the nuclear space in G1 (Figure 5d, Supplementary Figure 6h), a phenomenon clearly reminiscent of eu- and hetero chromatin compartments found in higher eukaryotes 20.

We next investigated the behavior of mosaic chromosomes in G2/M by performing Scc1 ChIP-seq and Hi-C. First, the Scc1 deposition pattern was highly conserved along native and mosaic chromosomes. Notably, the loss of cohesin at all centromeres was maintained (Supplementary Figure 6d). In addition, cohesin coating remained enriched over U-type Mmyco sequences although to a lower level, including over the 50 kb encompassed within 850 Mb of yeast DNA on XVIfMmycot2 chromosome. These results show that cohesin is loaded along inactive Mmyco regions independently of the proximity with the centromere (as along WT chromosomes), and independently of transcription. The larger chromatin context plays little if no role in this cohesin-mediated loading. The only noticeable differences resulting from the fusion/translocation events in G2/M Hi-C contact maps (Supplementary Figure 6f) were observed at the junction between Mmyco and the endogenous yeast sequences. There, a DNA loop appears over the boundary (Supplementary Figure 6g). The two anchors of the loop consisted, on the one hand, in a strongly cohesin-enriched region already present on chr. XV sequence, and on the other hand, in another region slightly enriched in cohesin already present on the Mmyco sequence (Supplementary Figure 6g). Together with observations from the previous section, these results show that Y and U chromatin types are both prone to dynamic cohesin-dependent DNA compaction and loop formation in G2/M phase (Figure 5d) and further suggest that loop extrusion can proceed through the Y/U chromatin junction to form a loop bridging the nearest cohesin enrichment sites on each side 19,47.

At a broader scale, Hi-C maps of the mosaic chromosomes in G2/M show that U-type compartments disappear upon cohesin-mediated compaction (Supplementary Figure 6f). The analysis of distance-dependent contact frequency shows that all chromosome regions behave similarly at this stage (Supplementary Figure 6e, G2/M). This observation shows that, as observed in multicellular organisms, LE mediated metaphase chromosome compaction abolishes chromatin compartments to prepare chromosomes for segregation (Figure 5d) 45,48,49.

sec.title: Chromatin structure and activity is driven by the sequence composition
sec.p: In this work, we show that bacterial DNA sequences introduced in a eukaryotic cellular context into which they have not evolved behave in a way that is largely predictable by neural networks trained on endogenous sequences. This suggests that the cellular machinery is extremely robust, and indiscriminately processes any sequence. The GC% content nevertheless appears as an important driver of chromatin activity as two different values lead to the formation of two archetypes of chromatin, that we call here Y and U for Yeast-like and Unstructured, reminiscent of the mammalian active euchromatin and inactive heterochromatin found in A and B compartments, respectively. In both chromatin types, DNA is covered with histones, as this association only depends on the attraction between positively charged proteins and the negatively charged double helix, but low levels of GC are not compatible with the wrapping of DNA into nucleosomes. We hypothesize that this could be due to the frequent occurrence of poly(A) motifs that are known to prevent the formation of nucleosomes 27. The coating of the DNA molecule with histones may result in the presence of intra nucleosomal patches / hydrophobic interaction along the molecule that are prone to sticky interactions. The resulting self-attracting potential would lead to the collapse of the whole region into a globule 50, and to the colocalization of dispersed U-type chromatin domains into a new compartment, in agreement with both the observed p(s) and FiSH microscopy images. We also observed a correlation between this compact, globular state and a suppression of transcription, although we cannot conclude here about causal relationship. In metaphase, the SMC cohesin complex binds to all exogenous sequences, regardless of their transcriptional status and GC content, and appears to start extruding DNA loops through an active ATPase dependent process 16,51. Along Y chromatin, these complexes accumulate at convergent transcription loci 33,43,52. Along U chromatin, in the absence of well-defined nucleosomes and transcription, translocation of the cohesin complex occurs uniformly all along the molecule, leading to a homogeneous enrichment pattern.

The existence of these alternative chromatin types has important implications in synthetic biology and genomics: the sequence composition should be taken into account when engineering new chromosomal segments. The performance of deep learning models to learn chromatin composition from sequences establishes these approaches as must-have steps in the validation of the compatibility of any sequence design, including data storage, prior synthesis and integration.

sec.title: Prokaryotic DNA contains some determinants of transcription orientation in eukaryote
sec.p: Previous works have characterized the behavior of exogenous DNA within the yeast nucleus. For instance, short stretches or small (13 kb) random DNA sequences can be used to generate yeast promoters and to decipher the regulatory logic of transcription activation 53–55. Here we show that both normal GC% and AT-rich bacterial chromosomes are spontaneously transcribed when introduced in the yeast eukaryotic environment 6,13,56. Active transcription follows, on average, the orientation of the bacteria genes (Figure 3c). Several mechanisms can account for this observation. The Nonsense-Mediated Decay (NMD) complex, which destabilizes eukaryotic transcripts with long 3’ UTR, could be frequently activated by bacteria antisense RNA compared to sense RNA. Alternatively, bacteria codon usage bias may also result in enrichment in Nrd1-Nab3-Sen1 (NNS) binding sites along the ncRNA strand, leading to transcription termination 57. Another, more speculative possibility is that sequence determinants predating the divergence of eucaryotes and procaryotes drive the preferred orientation of the RNA polII. Whatever the cause, the resulting conserved orientation could facilitate the domestication of exogenous sequences during horizontal transfer/introgression events between distant species. Whether these RNA molecules are translated and peptides of bacterial origins exist in the yeast cell remains to be determined. If so, they could provide a source of diversity and adaptation.

sec.title: Cohesin-mediated loop formation along non-transcribed DNA templates
sec.p: Our results on long exogenous sequences provide new insights on the mechanisms behind cohesin-mediated loops. They suggest that cohesin (1) can be loaded on long lowly transcribed DNA sequences, independently of centromere vicinity or active promoters, and (2) compacts DNA along these regions, without forming visible DNA loops with discrete anchors. The positions of loop anchors have been proposed to be determined by the combination of convergent transcription, replication fork progression during S phase and/or stably bound cohesin at cohesin associated regions 42,43,58. Loop positioning, stabilization and maintenance at discrete loci also involves Eco1 dependent acetylation of cohesin Smc3 43,51,59,60. We propose that low transcription accounts for the absence of large DNA loop positioning at discrete loci along the Mmyco chromosome. Our results also suggest that transcription may not be considered as a primary molecular motor for cohesin mediated loop extrusion, although transcription interferes with loop extrusion process 58. In agreement with in vitro data 16, cohesin expands DNA loops in vivo independently of its chromatinization and transcription status, sequence composition and GC% content, resulting in chromosome compaction.

On a transcribed chromosome, cohesin is strikingly located at convergent transcription sites as was observed for WT yeast chromosomes 33,34. We suggest that cohesin may be stopped and stabilized at these sites during processes of loop extrusion. Active transcription may therefore inhibit cohesin translocation and/or loading along the fiber, resulting in accumulation of the complex in non-transcribed regions.

sec.title: Compartmentalization of the genome
sec.p: The nucleus of WT yeast (and other fungi) is typically separated into two compartments: the active chromatin and the nucleolus containing rDNA. Here, we show that the introduction of non-transcribed AT-rich DNA is sufficient to spontaneously promote the formation of a third compartment reminiscent of the “B” compartment of inactive metazoan heterochromatin. This new compartment is positioned at the periphery of the nucleus, close to the nuclear envelope, so that the active chromatin occupies the central space of the nucleus (Figure 5d; Supplementary Figure 6h). The spontaneous segregation of a long DNA molecule that has not evolved in this context, based solely on its composition and resulting activity, could be highly significant with respect to genome invasion by exogenous mobile elements. One could predict, based on the properties revealed in our work, that a genome suddenly harboring a large amount of un-transcribed and divergent DNA will spontaneously maintain its original chromatin active while dramatically changing its 3D structure, in a way highly reminiscent of the described architecture in mammalian genomes in which heterochromatin at AT-rich transposable elements is positioned at the nuclear periphery.

caption.title: Chromatin composition of bacterial chromosomes in yeast.
caption.p: a, Schematic representation of the conversion from circular to linear chromosomes integrated in yeast. The purple and blue colors represent the M. pneumoniae (Mpneumo) and M. mycoides (Mmyco) bacterial sequence in all figures, respectively.

b, MNase-seq (top), PolII (middle) and Scc1 (bottom) ChIP-seq deposition profiles along three representative yeast chromosomes and, if present, the bacterial chromosome in i) wild-type, ii) Mpneumo and iii) Mmyco strains. Black triangles: centromere positions. Bin size: 10kb.
c, Magnification of PolII and Scc1 ChIP-seq profiles along 80 kb windows of i) a wt yeast chromosome, and ii) the Mpneumo and iii) Mmyco sequences. Bin size: 100bp.

caption.title: Deep-learning analysis of chromatin composition along yeast and bacterial chromosomes.
caption.p: a-c, Experimental (top) and NN prediction (bottom) of MNase-seq, Scc1 and PolII ChIP-seq coverage tracks over yeast and bacterial chromosomes Mmyco and Mpneumo in yeast, at the chromosome level and in 60kb-wide genomic loci.

d–f, Prediction of MNase-seq, Scc1 and PolII ChIP-seq average signal over random sequences with varying GC content. The average signals experimentally measured in yeast and along the Mmyco and Mpneumo bacterial chromosomes are overlaid at their corresponding GC content.

caption.title: Expression of exogenic bacterial sequences in budding yeast.
caption.p: a, RNA-seq profiles along three representative yeast chromosomes and, if present, the bacterial chromosome in i) wild-type, ii) Mpneumo and iii) Mmyco strains.

b, Top: stranded RNA-seq data along a 60kb window along either wt chr. VI, Mpneumo or Mmyco. The pink and turquoise colors represent forward and reverse transcription, respectively. The orientation of the genes along the yeast or bacterial sequences are indicated under the plot. Bottom: Scc1 (cohesin) deposition profiles of the corresponding region. Green dotted lines indicate identified loci of convergent transcription (see Methods).
c, Forward and reverse RNA-seq coverage of forward- and reverse-oriented yeast or bacterial genes in WT, Mpneumo and Mmyco strains. Scores were normalized by the length of each genomic feature.

d, Left: aggregated profile of Scc1 deposition centered at Scc1 peaks (+/- 4kb) called over chr. II (top) or Mpneumo (bottom), with peaks ordered by peak strength. Middle: corresponding stranded transcription tracks, colored according to their forward or reverse orientation. Right: for chr. II or Mpneumo chromosome, average forward and reverse transcription over the 20% strongest or 20% weakest Scc1 peaks.

caption.title: Folding of exogenic bacterial sequences within the yeast nucleus.
caption.p: a, b, Hi-C contact maps of representative endogenous and of Mmyco and Mpneumo bacterial chromosomes in G1 (a) and G2/M (b) (4kb resolution).
c, d, Contact frequency as a function of genomic distance plots of endogenous yeast chromosomes (long arms) and of Mmyco and Mpneumo bacterial chromosomes in G1 (c) and G2/M (d).

e, Left: FISH imaging. Representative field of either (top) Mpneumo or (bottom) Mmyco fixed cells labeled with DAPI (left panel) and hybridized with a fluorescent probe generated from either the Mpneumo or Mmyco chromosome, respectively. Right: For each probe, number of patches detected per nucleus and surface occupied by these patches relative to the whole nucleus surface (Methods).

f, g, Top: magnification of 150kb windows from Hi-C contact maps in G2/M from either an endogenous or the bacterial chromosome in Mpneumo (f) and Mmyco (g) strains (1kb resolution). Bottom: Scc1 ChIP-seq deposition profile. Black arrowheads: loops. Cyan diamonds: location of Scc1 peaks indicated on the main Hi-C diagonal in the Mpneumo chromosome.

h, Left: Distance measured between chromatin loop anchors in the Mpneumo chromosome and their nearest Scc1 peak, or expected after randomly shuffling the position of the loop anchors. Right: Scc1 peak strength for peaks located in yeast WT chromosomes or over the Mpneumo chromosome, near loop anchors (< 1kb) or outside of loop anchors.
i, Distance-dependent contact frequency in endogenous yeast chromosomes and in bacterial chromosomes in Mpneumo (left) and Mmyco (right) strains, in “wild-type” (dashed) and in Δwpl1 mutants.

caption.title: Compartmentalization of mosaic chromosomes composed of Y and U-type chromatin.
caption.p: a, Schematic representation of the CRISPR strategy used to generate the Mmyco mosaic chromosomes with alternating Y and U chromatin regions.

b, Top: G1 Hi-C contact maps of chr. XV, XVI, and bacterial chromosomes in the Mmyco strain, and in its derivative (i.e. the chr. XVI and Mmyco fusion, and the two strains with translocations resulting in Y and U chromatin alternation; Methods) (4kb resolution). Bottom: auto-correlation contact matrices in wt and mosaic chromosomes strains.

c, Virtual 4C profiles of viewpoints located within yeast chr. XVI (in grey) or Mmyco chromosome segments (in blue), in XVIfMmyco, XVIfMmycot1 and XVIfMmycot2 strains. The large grey/blue arrows indicate the location of each viewpoint. Note the increase in contacts of chr. XVI Y chromatin segments with distant segments of itself, and in alternance with decreased contacts with Mmyco U chromatin segments.

d, Schematic of a chimeric chromosome composed of alternating Y- and U-type chromatin. Left: composition of Y- and U-type chromatin. Middle: Spatial and functional organization in G1. Right: Organization of Y and U-type chromatin segments in G2/M.
